subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] learning
msgSnippet: Welcome! Here are some suggestions.  First, get the Kingsley Read manual in PDF form if you don t have it already. There is a Junior QS example paragraph which
messageBody:
Welcome!

Here are some suggestions. First, get the Kingsley Read manual in PDF
form if you don't have it already.

There is a Junior QS example paragraph which uses all the letters. With
key in hand, decode it like a cryptogram, sounding out all the words.
It will be slow going the first time.

Next, pick a few consonants and a few vowels from the list. Try to
write all the words you can think of that use those sounds. It would
be a good game to play with your son! Then pick another handful and
repeat.

Then, try to read the harder examples in the manual and do some practice
writing. It's a great way to keep a diary which few humans can read...

Finally, if you have your fonts in order, you can correspond with others
on this list. We'd all love to read your work.

Have fun,
- Mitch

On Tue, 2003-05-13 at 19:54, branain wrote:
> Hi all,
>
> I discovered this site and the Read Alphabet a few weeks ago. I
> decided to learn it. I really love it. Even my 10-year-old son has
> started to learn it.
>
> Do you have any suggestions on how to learn and practice this
> wonderful writting system?
>
> I pretty much can grasp all the sounds, but I have a little problem
> with the "ah" in "alms" & "ox" sounds. I pronounce them pretty much
> the same. I'm from New York, I wonder if that makes a difference? Is
> it acceptable to interchange them in my case, as I do not
> differentiate between them?
>
> Thanks,
> Chris
>
>
> Yahoo! Groups Sponsor

Welcome!

Here are some suggestions.  First, get the Kingsley Read manual in PDF
form if you don't have it already.  

There is a Junior QS example paragraph which uses all the letters.  With
key in hand, decode it like a cryptogram, sounding out all the words. 
It will be slow going the first time.

Next, pick a few consonants and a few vowels from the list.  Try to
write all the words you can think of that use those sounds.  It would
be a good game to play with your son! Then pick another handful and
repeat.

Then, try to read the harder examples in the manual and do some practice
writing.  It's a great way to keep a diary which few humans can read...

Finally, if you have your fonts in order, you can correspond with others
on this list.  We'd all love to read your work.

Have fun, 
 - Mitch

> 
> I pretty much can grasp all the sounds, but I have a little problem
